{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3595174,"name":"Gavin Bigham","username":"BadQmen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/badqmen/{size}/236661_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-17T23:42:21.662Z","cooked":"

We are using the generic photonvision algae object detection model on an Orange Pi 5, but are having issues with the model detecting reflections on the polycarbonate fences. These reflections have the same or greater confidence level as normal algae, making it hard to filter out.

How can we avoid these, or filter it? Has anyone else had these problems or is willing to lend an AI model that we could use?

Can you do something as simple as filtering it out if the algae is out of bounds of the field?

I would be tempted to attach a polarizing filter over the camera lens.

We dont localize the algae detentions, we only get the offset from the center of the camera to the center of the algae as of right now.

CPL filter. There will be some photography store near you
or there‚Äôs this Amazon.com

Any polarized sunglasses/ safety glasses would achieve a similar effect but with some unwanted tint.

Disclaimer: I‚Äôve never put one one a robot and I don‚Äôt know if it will cut all reflections or just some.

We had this problem waaaaay back in 2007 Rack ‚Äòn‚Äô Roll with the green light reflecting off the side walls. Our (autonomous) robot would drive straight then spin left to the wall to chase the reflection. We ended up putting a piece of cardboard as a blinder on the camera to fix it. YMMV.

The story goes that our mentor was behind Dean and Woodie puzzling over the cardboard as they watched the match, got it explained, and they looked at each other and said ‚Äúwe didn‚Äôt think of that.‚Äù

@Duncan_Macdonald‚Äôs picture reminds me of 2008 Overdrive ghost robots, also known as ‚ÄúPepper‚Äôs Ghosts‚Äù of Disney‚Äôs Haunted Mansion.

ghostbot1600√ó900 96.8 KB
